docs.lead_paragraph: Ten months ago when their baby girl, Grace, was born, Leon Wynter and his wife, Yvonne Parnell Wynter, finally ended -- or at least postponed -- an argument they had been having throughout the pregnancy: whether or not to circumcise a boy. ''When it came up, my wife said, 'No, I'm not going to let it happen,' '' said Mr. Wynter, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal and a journalism professor at Baruch College in New York City.
docs.abstract: American Academy of Pediatrics, which has had three different policies on circumcision in 30 years, now says data are 'not significant enough' to recommend routine circumcision; says, for first time, that if parents do circumcise son, relieving pain is essential, using numbing creams or injections that are found to be safe and effective; new report, which appears in March issue of journal Pediatrics, scrutinizes and partly discounts potential benefits of circumcision cited 10 years ago (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They baptize people, confirm them, preach to them, marry them, bury them, and now, like it or not, in the face of AIDS, priests, ministers and other members of the clergy are teaching parishioners about sex. And nowhere is the need felt more urgently than in places black people worship, whether Roman Catholic, Pentecostal or Muslim.

headline.main: Slowly Breaking the Silence on AIDS

docs.abstract: Black churches are at last facing up to issue of AIDS, which they have been slow to do even though AIDS continues to pose disproportionate peril to blacks; religious leaders are increasingly speaking out, sometimes uncomfortably, teaching prevention for healthy and compassion for stricken; their message is one of abstinence, monogamy, protection, including condoms, and avoidance of drugs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: They baptize people, confirm them, preach to them, marry them, bury them, and now, like it or not, in the face of AIDS, priests, ministers and other members of the clergy are teaching parishioners about sex.    And nowhere is the need felt more...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many ailments that afflict older Americans are directly caused or indirectly worsened by poor nutrition -- an inadequate intake of essential nutrients, dietary fiber and water. Health problems like heart disease, osteoporosis, diabetes, kidney disease and even cancer are influenced by the foods consumed, or not consumed, especially in older people. Poor choice of foods, rather than a shortage of finances, is the usual reason. Studies indicate that nutritional shortcomings are common among the elderly who are well-to-do as well as those with limited resources.

headline.main: Now, a Food Pyramid To Guide the Elderly

docs.abstract: Personal Health column notes many ailments afflicting older Americans are directly caused or indirectly worsened by poor nutrition; revised food guide pyramid for Americans over 70 has been developed by Dr Robert M Russell, Dr Alice Lichtenstein and Helen Rasmussen, registered dietition; guide has new foundation: eight 8-ounce glasses of water daily; suggested food guide is in March isue of The Journal of Nutrition; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Many ailments that afflict older Americans are directly caused or indirectly worsened by poor nutrition -- an inadequate intake of essential nutrients, dietary fiber and water. Health problems like heart disease, osteoporosis, diabetes, kidney...

docs.lead_paragraph: In trying to explain why fruits and vegetables help prevent cancer, some researchers cite flavonoids, which are chemical ingredients that inhibit cancer cell growth. But a new study suggests that tangeretin, a flavonoid in citrus fruits and certain processed foods and dietary supplements, may sometimes be harmful because it negates the benefits of tamoxifen, the breast cancer drug. The finding came as a surprise, since in vitro studies showed that tangeretin acted like tamoxifen to inhibit mammary cancer cells. Researchers from the University Hospital in Ghent, Belgium, wanted to see if tangeretin could amplify tamoxifen's therapeutic effect in mice with mammary cancer. Their study was published last month in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute. One group of the 80 mice drank water with tamoxifen, one drank water with tangeretin, one drank water with both substances and the fourth group served as a control. The tamoxifen group had significantly less tumor growth than the others and lived an average of 56 weeks, compared with just 14 weeks for the tangeretin-tamoxifen group.

headline.main: Surprise Finding on Tamoxifen and Citrus

docs.abstract: Some researchers trying to explain why fruits and vegetables help prevent cancer cite flavonoids, chemical ingredients that inhibit cancer cell growth; new study suggests that tangeretin, flavonoid in citrus fruits and certain processed foods and dietary supplements, may sometimes be harmful because it negates benefits of tamoxifen, breast cancer drug (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As a nurse holds the hands and head of one of the seven surviving octuplets born in Houston in December, a doctor peers at the back of the eyes through an ophthalmosocope. In assembly line fashion, the eye doctor examines each child. The aim is to seek the earliest sign of a condition known as retinopathy of prematurity, resulting from abnormal blood vessel growth, and to use a laser to prevent a detached retina, which can cause blindness. The octuplets were born nearly four months before the mother's due date of April 1. Like other infants born many weeks too early, they are at high risk of developing retinopathy in both eyes.

headline.main: Staving Off Blindness in the Tiniest of Infants

docs.abstract: Infants born many weeks premature run high risk of developing potentially blinding eye condition known as retinopathy of prematurity; at least 55,000 babies born prematurely each year are at highest risk, and about 1,000 of them suffer severe visual impairment or blindness from the condition; figures would be much higher if pediatric ophthalmologists did not use lasers or freezing technique to try to limit damage; diagrams (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: LASER (LIGHT AMPLIFICATION BY STIMULATED EMISSION OF RADIATION)

docs.lead_paragraph: When a woman finds out that she has breast cancer, fear and depression may be quickly followed by overwhelming confusion. There are so many decisions to make about surgery, radiation, types of chemotherapy and hormonal treatment that women may wonder how to make sure they really are getting the best, most up-to-date advice. Now, the American Cancer Society and the National Comprehensive Cancer Network, a group of 17 cancer centers, have published breast-cancer treatment guidelines that they say are the first written specifically to give patients information on ''gold-standard cancer treatment.''
docs.abstract: American Cancer Society and National Comprehensive Cancer Network publish breast-cancer treatment guidelines that were written specifically to give patients information on 'gold-standard' cancer treatment; some cancer experts have reservations about guidelines, finding them too dense for average consumer and objecting to guidelines' call for more aggressive testing and treatment than many physicians would recommend, particularly for small tumors (M)
docs.snippet: When a woman finds out that she has breast cancer, fear and depression may be quickly followed by overwhelming confusion. There are so many decisions to make about surgery, radiation, types of chemotherapy and hormonal treatment that women may wonder...

docs.lead_paragraph: Although mouth guards can prevent dental injuries that occur during contact sports, a University of Minnesota study says that few athletes are wearing them. Half of the 318 soccer players, basketball players and wrestlers who participated in the study believed mouth guards could help prevent injuries, but only 6 percent reported using them.

headline.main: Mouths at Risk When Guards Are Out

docs.abstract: University of Minnesota study says few athletes are wearing mouth guards, although it has been proven they prevent dental injuries that occur during contact sports; most athletes cite discomfort wearing guards; photo (S)
